title: Squid in Cuisine (Calamari)
summary: Squid, often known culinarily as calamari, is a widely consumed seafood globally. Its versatility allows for numerous preparations, including common fried dishes in the Mediterranean and Western countries, raw consumption in Korea and Japan as sushi or sashimi, and grilled forms in Asia. Edible parts encompass the mantle, arms, tentacles, and ink, while the beak and gladius are discarded. Beyond main dishes, squid is popular as a dried shredded snack in Asian regions and features prominently as bar snacks, street food, and starters worldwide, incorporated into stir-fries, rice, and noodle dishes.
key_points: The culinary name 'calamari' is frequently used for squid dishes, especially fried preparations.
Squid is prepared in diverse ways globally, including frying, grilling, stewing, serving raw (sushi, sashimi), and drying into snacks.
All parts of the squid (mantle, arms, tentacles, ink) are edible, excluding only the beak and gladius (pen).
It is a common ingredient in various cuisines, notably Mediterranean, East Asian, and Southeast Asian.
Dried shredded squid is a popular pre-packaged snack in several Asian countries and Russia.

current_status: Squid is a globally popular and widely consumed seafood item, integrated into many traditional and contemporary cuisines worldwide. It is readily available in various forms, from fresh preparations to pre-packaged snacks, across numerous retail and dining establishments.
future_prospects: The content does not explicitly discuss future trends or prospects for squid consumption. However, given its current widespread popularity, continued global consumption and adaptation into new culinary contexts are probable, with potential for ongoing innovation in preparation methods and fusion with emerging food trends.
